All Revenue is Not Created Equal

The Keys to the 10X Revenue Club

By Bill Gurley, Above the Crowd

May 24, 2011

Listen to this article
Click to play
1x
1.5x
2x
"Don't you know that you are a shooting star,
And all the world will love you just as long,
As long as you are." - Paul Rodgers, Shooting Star

With the IPO market blown wide-open and the media infatuated with frothy valuations, it's common to see articles that reference both "valuation" and "revenue" and suggest a correlation between the two. But investors beware: the price/revenue ratio is a remarkably dangerous tool, because all revenues are not created equal.

The 100X Disparity

Consider this: analyzing 122 global internet stocks reveals a staggering range of price/revenue multiples. On one end is Overstock, trading at 0.2X revenue estimates. On the other end is Youku.com, trading at 21.7X revenue. That's a 100X difference in value per sales dollar.

The Distribution is Heavily Skewed Over 72% of companies have a price/revenue multiple below 4x. Only 12 of 122 companies (less than 10%) have multiples over 7X. Only 5 are above 10X. The press tends to favor higher multiples as "defaults," but only a handful of companies deserve to be in the "10X club."

What Drives True Equity Value?

Those of us with a fondness for finance will argue that discounted cash flows (DCF) are the true drivers of value. The problem is that it's nearly impossible to predict long-term cash flows for young companies with innovative business models. What's the long-term growth rate? Operating margin? Competitive durability? Reinvestment requirements?

Value = Future Cash Flows / Discount Rate
The DCF is theoretically correct but practically difficult without accurate inputs

Because DCF is unwieldy for young companies, investors use shortcuts. But the price/revenue multiple is the crudest of them all.

The 10 Characteristics of High-Multiple Companies

While you might not have specific DCF inputs, you can identify business qualities that would have a positive impact on long-term cash flows. Companies with these traits are said to have high "revenue quality."

Sustainable Competitive Advantage

Warren Buffett's "moat." How easy is it for someone else to provide the same product or service? High barriers to entry allow investors to confidently discount cash flows many years into the future.

Network Effects

Perhaps the strongest moat of all. When value to each customer is a direct function of customers already in the system, you have a powerful winner-take-all dynamic. Microsoft, eBay, Skype, Google AdWords, and Facebook all benefited from network effects.

Visibility / Predictability

Investors favor pricing models with high predictability. Subscription revenue (SAAS) trades at premium multiples. One-time or episodic revenue (games, consulting) commands much lower multiples.

Customer Lock-in / Switching Costs

Retaining customers for long periods is highly valued. Companies with excessively low churn rates (5% annually or less) are very likely to have top-decile price/revenue multiples.

Gross Margin Levels

You cannot generate much cash from revenue saddled with large variable costs. Amazon (20% margin) trades at 1.5x revenue. Wal-Mart (25%) at 0.41x. Best Buy (24%) at only 0.22x.

Marginal Profitability

Investors love companies with scale - where higher revenues create higher profit margins. If marginal profitability is higher than historical, the company is scaling nicely.

Customer Concentration

A fragmented customer base is preferable. Large customers have "market power" leading to pricing and service demands. The ideal: tons of small customers who are essentially "price takers."

Partner Dependencies

Heavy dependence on another partner creates risk. Demand Media's reliance on Google SEO traffic, for example, creates uncertainty that compresses multiples regardless of current performance.

Organic Demand

Heavy marketing reliance hurts valuation. If you have to "buy" or "rent" your customers, you have a non-optimal business model. The best companies grow through word of mouth.

Growth

Nothing contributes to higher multiples like growth. But growth alone can be misleading - growth that can never translate into positive cash flow has a negative impact on DCF, not positive.

The Moat Comparison

Coca-Cola vs. RIM: A Tale of Two Moats

Coca-Cola has a 5% estimated growth rate and a 3.6x price/revenue multiple. RIM has a 12% estimated growth rate and only 0.77x multiple. Why? Investors expect Coke to exist in its same form 50 years from now. It's much harder to say that with confidence about RIM.

Network Effects: The Ultimate Moat

In Brian Arthur's seminal HBR piece "Increasing Returns and Two Worlds of Business" (1996), he describes a world where the market leader has an unfair advantage reinforced by network effects. Important caveats:

  • Strength varies. What matters is the decay rate of value of incremental users to the customer value function.
  • They're rarer than claimed. Many things identified as network effects are merely economies of scale, which are far less powerful.
  • When they exist, they're 10X candidates. Microsoft, eBay, Skype, Google AdWords, Facebook - all benefited from true network effects.

The Visibility Spectrum

Revenue Predictability and Valuation Multiples

Games
1.7-2x Hardware
2-3x Netflix
3-4x SAAS
7-8x
Episodic / Hit-driven Subscription / Recurring

Salesforce vs. Electronic Arts

Salesforce trades at 7.5x revenue. EA trades at 1.7x. Both are successful companies, but Salesforce's subscription model provides predictable recurring revenue that investors value at a premium. EA's hit-driven game business creates uncertainty about future cash flows.

The Organic Growth Premium

Consider two stores in the middle of town. One has customers flocking in through word of mouth. The other relies on advertising for every customer. Which would you prefer to own?

The Skype Example Skype's cost of acquiring a new user was $0.001 versus $400 for Vonage. Which company deserved a higher price/revenue multiple? The answer is obvious.

Jeff Bezos himself retreated from heavy marketing: "About three years ago we stopped doing television advertising... More and more money will go into making a great customer experience, and less will go into shouting about the service. Word of mouth is becoming more powerful."

The Growth Trap: Profitless Prosperity

Growth is crucial, but it can be misleading. Growth that can never translate into positive cash flow has a negative impact on DCF. In the late 1990s, when Wall Street paid for "revenue" not "profits," entrepreneurs figured out how to manufacture revenue growth.

The $0.85 Dollar Business
What if I sold dollars for $0.85? Revenue would explode. But that's not a real business. Any business where value transfer to customers and suppliers cannot sustain positive profit is the same trap.

The 10X Club Scorecard

Does Your Company Qualify?

1 Sustainable competitive advantage (moat)
2 Strong network effects
3 High revenue visibility/predictability
4 Strong customer lock-in
5 High gross margins (60%+)
6 Increasing marginal profitability
7 Fragmented customer base
8 No major partner dependencies
9 Organic customer acquisition
10 Strong, sustainable growth

LinkedIn: A 10X Club Case Study

At its IPO, LinkedIn's market cap was $8.3 billion, trading between 11.8-15x 2012 revenue estimates. This attracted global scrutiny. But LinkedIn scores extremely well on the 10X criteria:

Criterion LinkedIn Score
Growth Strong
Barriers to Entry Very High
Network Effects Strong
Dependencies Minimal
Profitability Expansion Needs Improvement

Assuming LinkedIn shows profit expansion over coming years, the 10X multiple isn't unreasonable.

Update: Additional Factors

Based on reader feedback, a few more factors worth mentioning:

  • Capital Expenditure Intensity - Heavy CapEx requires constant funding that dilutes shares or uses earned cash.
  • Cash Flow vs. Earnings - Companies generating more cash than earnings (collecting cash before revenue recognition) command premium multiples.
  • Optionality - Strong market position can create options on new businesses. Amazon's AWS was an "option" that began to be valued as such.
  • TAM (Total Available Market) - Can affect private valuations dramatically, though less so for public companies with optionality into other markets.

The Bottom Line

Fundamentals Eventually Matter If we've learned anything from past market cycles, it's that fundamentals eventually matter, and all revenues are decidedly not created equal. The 10X club is reserved for companies with exceptional revenue quality - not just growth, but sustainable competitive advantages that translate into long-term cash flows.

Many hot companies with lofty private valuations would not score well on the 10X scorecard. Over the next 12-18 months, as they test public markets with truly liquid marketplaces, we gain a better appreciation for real valuation.
